title: Is it okay to ask for gift cards for a bridal shower? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can ask for gift cards but do it with taste. My wedding clientele is mostly upscale and they never include any information about gifts / gift registries and such in their invitations, whether it’s for their bridal shower or wedding celebration. If guests ask and want to give something, the information is communicated personally (by the couple or the parents) in person, by phone or via email. As other Quora users stated here before me, you shouldn’t assume that people give you gifts however, it’s customary. Just don’t make it obvious for them.

It’s kind of tacky, honestly. A shower is traditionally thrown to ‘shower’ the couple with gifts for their new/combined home. And traditionally, the person being showered opens the gifts and carries on about them. That’s kind of pointless with gift cards or money. And it’s always rude to ask for money, I don’t care what Honeyfund tells you. Everyone needs something; that’s why there are registries. If you truly don’t need a thing, then don’t have a shower. Problem solved.

I’m not particularly fond of asking for gift cards as a bridal shower present, but I can understand it in some instances. There was a shower I attended where the couple asked for gift cards to Home Depot. They had been living together for a few years and moved into an older home that needed some work. They had household things that one needs to begin a life together. Honestly, I would have rather just given them money, but I gave the gift card requested

No. It is just not done to assume people will give you gifts I know, I know, you are saying the purpose of a shower is to give you gifts. But, remember the tradition started when older women helped brides get set up in housekeeping by giving them practical gifts that they knew were needed. Never be so presumptious as to tell others what to give you for a gift. Be grateful that people came to help you celebrate.

I think that is tacky to do . Better to let the person know who is throwing you a shower to spread the word for gift cards through friends and family who will be attending the shower . Also it’s bit anti climactic to watch someone opening gift cards for their presents . A few are fine but all gift cards ?
Tacky, tacky, tacky. Why not just put a big tip jar by the front door? You can then pick up some cash from serving refreshments.
It’s tacky to ask. Notify your mother and the person giving the shower that if anyone asks what you want a gift card would be acceptable.
